title: How to Bisect a Line With a Compass and Straightedge

steps.title: Draw the line segment you need to bisect.
steps.content: Draw the line segment you need to bisect. If the line segment is not already given, you will need to make it using a straightedge.

steps.title: Choose an appropriately sized compass.
steps.content: Choose an appropriately sized compass. If you open the compass completely, and it spans one-half the length of the line or less, you need to choose a bigger compass. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Position the compass on an endpoint.
steps.content: Position the compass on an endpoint. To do this, place the needle of the compass on either endpoint. Open the compass so that it spans a little more than half the length of the line. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Draw an arc above and below the line segment.
steps.content: Draw an arc above and below the line segment. Make sure the needle stays on the endpoint, and that you do not adjust the compass setting. [3] X Research source The length of the arcs does not matter.

steps.title: Reposition the compass on the other endpoint.
steps.content: Reposition the compass on the other endpoint. Make sure you do not change the compass setting. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Draw another set of arcs, above and below the line segment.
steps.content: Draw another set of arcs, above and below the line segment. Make sure the needle stays on the endpoint, and that you do not adjust the compass setting. [5] X Research source The two sets of arcs youâ€™ve drawn should intersect.

steps.title: Connect the arc intersections.
steps.content: Connect the arc intersections. To do this, place your straightedge on the point where the arcs above the line intersect, and align it with the point where the arcs below the line intersect. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Draw your perpendicular bisector.
steps.content: Draw your perpendicular bisector. The line you draw between the two arc intersections bisects the line at a ninety degree angle. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Understand why this works.
steps.content: Understand why this works. You have used the compass to outline two congruent circles centered over either endpoint. The intersecting arcs represent the endpoint of a radii from the center of either circle. [8] X Research source The length of the radii will be the same, since the circles are the same size.
